electronics.name: RC tank project
electronics.introduction: During my undergraduate degree I volunteered in the Humanoid Robotics Lab and got to learn a lot about robotics and computer engineering. This inspired me to want to learn more by learning how RC cars work and how I can make my own. This project has so many components I will need to learn about that this can really be considered an unending project, there is always another thing that I can add. To avoid this endless scope creep, I set this up in iterations where I set some goals for each iteration and conclude it when those goals have been reached.

iterations.title: Iteration 1: Trial run
iterations.introduction: The main goals of this iteration are to learn about the components that are in a remote controlled car. As a Computer Scientist, I am interested in knowing how I can make this general purpose as well, meaning that once I get the components running I want to be able to add more advanced hardware and software like a live feed camera and an accelerometer.

components.text: Jada Toys -2015 Dodge Challenger SRT Hellcat

blurbs.title: Remote Control Car Components
blurbs.text:
The main components needed for a minimum viable remote control car are a general purpose computer, a motor controller, motors, and a power source.

The first thing we need is some kind of compute chip. This chip can be embedded or something more general purpose. Examples of embedded are Arduino and the Raspberry Pi Pico. These do not have an operating system and will instead execute some code upon startup. On the other hand a general purpose computer would have an operating system as well as all the things around it. This means that we can run a script on startup, but we can also do more advanced things like running multiple software and installing frameworks. Examples of general purpose computers to use for this would be Raspberry Pi zero and up. In this trial I will use what is available to me and use the Raspberry Pi 3B+ as I have one lying around.

The second component we need is a motor control board. There are a couple of reasons this is a requirement. First, the motor is likely running on a much higher voltage and current than the computer so we cannot connect a motor directly to the computer. Second, the direction of spin on the motor alternates with the current. Meaning, there is no real + or - on an electric motor but rather it will spin in different directions based on which direction the power is connected. Fun fact, if you use an external source to spin the motor it will generate electricity. The motor controller allows for the current to be switched either way. The compute module will then communicate commands to the motor controller using Pulse Width Modulation (PWM) to control the motor speed and direction.

The motors are likely just going to be brushed motors. In my case I will start with using an existing RC car so I can skip the motor gearbox and steering for now.

The power source will need to be sufficient for the whole system. In my case I will use a separate power source for the compute module and the motors, this may change in later revisions.

images.alt: This is the result of the first iteration of this project.

blurbs.title: Connecting The Motor Control Module
blurbs.text: A common motor controller for beginners I found was the L298N Module H Bridge Driver. There are amazing guides on how to connect the L298N to a Raspberry Pi and use a simple python script to control the motors. This tutorial also introduces how to use PWMs, allowing you to control the motor speed. Comparatively, without making use of PWM the motors can only switch to full power or no power, i.e. on or off. I used a separate power source for the computer and the motors. The computer is using a phone power bank and the motors have 3 AA batteries in series to get 3.6v (underneath the phone power bank).

blurbs.title: Connecting an Xbox One controller to a Raspberry PI
blurbs.text: The Raspberry Pi model I own has Bluetooth which means that it was possible to connect an Xbox one controller. Sometimes the connection will not work when attempting to reconnect the controller. To fix it, remove the controller from the list of Bluetooth devices using remove MAC_ADDRESS. Once the device is removed, attempt to reconnect it. A quick way of testing if the connection worked is to run cat /dev/input/event0. This simply prints out the device input as characters. Basically, you should see a lot of garbage showing up when you push buttons.

blurbs.title: Writing a script
blurbs.text: The last step of the process is to connect it all using python scripts. The first step is to import the IO libraries which is then followed by the buttons. We already have an example of how to map the pinouts from the Raspberry Pi. Here is the code I made for this:

blurbs.text:
In short, gpiozero is a library that allows you to access the General Purpose Input Output Pins (GPIO). Please see the latest gpiozero documentation and to get the pinout of your Pi user the pinout command.

We will be using the evdev library for reading user inputs, in this case the bluetooth controller.

Lines 11 and 12 are setting up the pins that will be used for the motors, see how to use Motor().

Lines 14 to 21 are mapping the buttons from the controller to variables. These were obtained by using cat /dev/input/your_input_device on Linux, which simply listens to the input channel and displays it on the screen. For example, when you press a on the controller the input read by the computer is 304. This is a unique value that will allow us to determine what button is pressed.

The way we know a button is pressed is by setting up an event listener for the controller, see line 87. If we are able to successfully create an event listener, then we listen, see line 24.

Line 26 checks what type of event, since the controller filters the events by type of button. Specifically, this statement filter for the ABXY buttons on the controller, the other events including triggers and joysticks are handled after line 42.

The button press events are handled on lines 29 to 41. The button press is a boolean event meaning the button is pressed or not.

The trigger, on the other hand, allows for values from 0 to 1023. On line 47 we check for the right trigger (line 54 for left trigger), then we take the read value and normalize it on line 48 to make it a value between 0 and 1. Then we can use the PWM, which is already packaged into the Motor() class and allows us to set a speed between 0 and 1, where 1 is the max speed of the motors.

Lines 62 to 70 checks if the user is using the controller d-pad to drive. The d-pad is also like a button so it will also be a motors on or off style.

Lastly, we read the joystick values on lines 74 to 83. As you can see on line 75, the joystick has a values between 65535 in total. That means that half is for -x and the other half is for +x, same is true for y. In this case we are only reading the y value to go forwards or backwards. On lines 78 to 83 we apply the speed values from the joystick.

blurbs.title: Result
blurbs.text:
Alright, it's not going to win any beauty pageants but it works!

Using PWM I was able to control the rate of acceleration using the triggers and joysticks. The motor controller was too weak to run the motors at full power and the whole setup was slow and hard to steer. Overall this project is a success, the main idea of it worked and it gave me a lot of data to know what to improve for the next iteration.

iterations.title: Iteration 2:
iterations.introduction: In the previous iteration I realised that the motor controller is too weak. In this iteration, I want to solve the power problem which likely will include the motor controller as well as batteries. Additionally, for what I am running the Raspberry Pi 3B+ is too large so for now we will switch to something smaller.

components.text: Jada Toys -2015 Dodge Challenger SRT Hellcat
DBH-1A Dual-Channel H Bridge Motor Driver Board Module

blurbs.title: Upgrading motor control board: DBH-1A Dual-Channel H Bridge Motor Driver
blurbs.text:
The L298N has a maximum current of around 2A, we need to upgrade to carry that level of current. For this, I will test the DBH-1A which is rated for up to 30A. The documentation for this board is not great, the best I can find is this blury image on AliExpress.us. The main idea of how these work is the same, with a couple of differences.

The differences are V+ and CT. This board is powered by the power source conneted to it. So, V+ is a 5v output to power external devices... I found that one out the hard way. According to AliExpress.us, CT is "the drive current" and the usage is "CT Output Voltage(V)=Current(A) x 0.155" to "do current-limiting processing". It seems that figuring out what CT is will need some investigating.

Otherwise, everything else is similar as the L298N Module H Bridge Driver, IN1 and IN2 are the PWM controllers for A and B output channels, respectively. And, EN enables each channel. GND is ground as always.

Since we are using a small compute board we can use the DBH-1A V+ output to power our Raspberry Pi Pico W through the VSYS pin, to clean up the wiring. This means that we will not have to have two power sources, one for the computer and one for the motors, like we did in Iteration 1. Note, the Raspberry Pi Pico W can run on a range of 1.8V - 5.5V, since I am using two 18650 batteries in parallel, I could connect the Raspberry Pi Pico W directly to the power source.

blurbs.title: The code
blurbs.text:
The first thing I noticed is that since Raspberry Pi Pico does not have an operating system, it does not have network software automatically running. In short, I have to write the bluetooth protocol myself. There are some bluetooth examples provided in the micropython github repo. As I dug into this more and more I realised that I would have to write the entire protocol for this device. Since the objective of the program was not to rewrite the bluetooth protocol, I will leave that for now.

Using other methods, I did test that this code does properly work. The motors can be controlled at variable speeds using the PWM and the enable worked as well.

blurbs.title: Results
blurbs.text:
The issue of not having enough power going to the motors was solved using the new motor control board. I was able to improve on the overall circuit layout and make it much simpler. However, due to not having an operating system, I would have to write the entire bluetooth protocol for it and this was not the objective of the project. As such, I will say that in the next iterations I will either revert to a Raspberry Pi with an operating system or switch to a stronger signal since that is already the plan. This was also just an excuse to work with the Pico W, and they are really fun and absolutely perfect for embedded applications.

What you cannot see in this picture is the on off switch neatly tucked underneath the motor control board, easily accessible from the bottom hatch. Also, the plastic cover does fit on this making it look as though nothing changed!

electronics.name: Electric Drill
electronics.introduction: Electric drills are not as complicated as you may think. I wanted to know more about them so I took apart an old drill my brother got at a flea market.

iterations.title: Introduction
iterations.introduction: Recently my brother happened to find an old electric drill at a local flea market and I figured this would be a good project to learn more about how electric drills work. The drill is in decent shape but it is old. We tried it and it did not work, and initially we thought we would just scrap it for parts. Afterall, there is a large electric motor, a motor controller, and a battery and if even 1 of those works then the $5 investment my brother made was worth it. After some investigation, we noticed that the motor and motor controller are still fully operational, but the batteries are all done. When I saw the batteries are done, I mean 0 volts and visibly oxidised.

blurbs.title: Project outline
blurbs.text: When testing the components individually, I realised that the entire tool still works and only the batteries are shot. This means that we can replace the batteries that match the voltage and potentially still see function out of this drill. If nothing else, the motor and motor controller appear to be in good shape and that alone is worth more than $5.

blurbs.title: Drill components
blurbs.text: The drill itself is as simple as a machine can get. It is also so old that I cannot find the exact model online, it is a 14.4v Bosch Brute drill. The image is the cross section of the drill with the parts annotated. The first component is the Chuck, which is used to fasten the drill bits to the motor. The second component is the Gearbox, basically including gears that allow for more torque or more speed controlled by the switch at the top. Third, the Electric Motor, a device that converts electricity into mechanical rotation. The fourth component is a Motor Controller, which allows the user to set different speeds for the motor by allowing a higher or lower voltage into the motor. Note, a general rule of thumb is that a higher voltage will provide higher speed whereas more amperage will provide more torque. The motor controller is likely the most technical part of all of this but there are really just a couple of mosfets, switches, diodes, and a spring. And lastly, the Battery that powers the device, in this case they appear to be Nickel–cadmium batteries.

images.name: electric_drill_annot
images.alt: An electric drill with the cover taken off and the parts annotated.

blurbs.title: Fixing the drill
blurbs.text:
Instead of stripping it for parts or throwing it out, I want to see if I can get this operational again. First, for the batteries I will use three 18650 batteries in series, making a 3.7v * 3 = 11.1v battery. Note, when these are charged full they are at 4.2v each making 12.6v in total. Since taking 4 batteries results in a range that goes over, I will stick with a little under.

To charge the batteries I will simply buy a charger that is meant for 3S batteries and put that in with the battery pack. To supply power for charging I will use a USB-C decay capable of delivering 12v.

electronics.name: Dehumidifier
electronics.introduction: To make a dehumidifier you need a source of cold, since as air cools it drops moisture. One method of converting electricity into cold is using a Thermoelectric Cooler or Peltier Cooler. I happen to have a couple of TECs and old computer fans lying around and thought I might try making a small dehumidifier.

iterations.title: Iteration 1: Trial run
iterations.introduction: First I need to understand the main components that make up the dehumidifier, including things like airflow. There are electrical components that are meant to interact with the physical world, meaning that we need to get a thorough understanding of the physics as well as the electrical components.

guides.name: Car OBD II
guides.introduction: Most modern cars use what is known as On-board diagnostic, abbreviated to OBD II. I did some research so I can do basic diagnostics on my car.

blurbs.title: Connecting to Bluetooth
blurbs.text:
Connect the OBD II scanner into the slot in your car, it's often near the driver's seat. I used Linux on my laptop to connect to the bluetooth device. The device will pair but does not connect so I had to connect a raw serial terminal to a bluetooth connection. All inputs are considered files and if you know where they are, /dev/ in Linux, you can open and read them like a file.
To connect to the raw serial use the command sudo rfcomm connect /dev/rfcomm0 MAC_ID 1 &. For more context, /dev/ is where input device files generally reside. This command creates a file to facilitate the communication, rfcomm is the bluetooth protocol

blurbs.title: Scanner software
blurbs.text: There are a couple of open source options to read the scanner output. I used a program that was based on pyOBD. The version of pyOBD I used had been reworked a little and it worked well. The documentation provided was straight forward and I followed it to get the program running. After the setup, use python3 pyobd.py to run the program. Another option is the python OBD library for more finetuned control of the data.

guides.name: CUPS: Remote printer
guides.introduction: My dad got an old printer from a garage sale and though the printer is excellent it does not have wireless printing. The printer itself is of good quality and for a few dollars it was worth the money. Instead of trying to find some fancy printer, I decided to try to see if I can find a workaround for this. And since I like learning new things, especially related to tech, that is exactly what I did. I used CUPS to along with my Raspberry Pi 3B+ to turn the printer into a wireless printer!

blurbs.text:
1. Install CUPS using: https://www.raspberrypi.com/news/printing-at-home-from-your-raspberry-pi/
  2. To turn the Raspberrry Pi into a print server use: https://www.tomshardware.com/how-to/raspberry-pi-print-server

  4. Find your printer driver online

1. First check that you have a compatible graphics card. CUDA is specifically designed for NVIDIA GPUs.

plants.name: Sarracenia
plants.introduction: Sarracenia is a species of carnivorous plants, also sometimes referred to as a Trumpet Pitcher Plant. These plants are quite unique in almost every aspect about them. I got my first Sarracenia from my grandmother in 2022. I now have two subspecies of the plant.

iterations.title: Sarracenias in general
iterations.introduction: Since these are two subspecies of each other they share a lot of common traits. The first fact I want to state is that these plants do not have moving parts that they use to catch their prey. And though you may think these plants are not going to survive they are excellent at what they do, catching insects. Everything from the shape to their taste and smell are designed to make them merciless bug hunters. I have two sub-special Sarracenia Farnhamii and Sarracenia purpurea. One source I used is provided by Tom's Carnivores, which is in depth and has nice vo

blurbs.title: Shared traits: Background
blurbs.text:
These plants exist primarily in the North Americas. That's right, right here in our own homes! The environment these plants are adapted to live in are bogs and wet grasslands. These environments are generally not well shaded due to larger plants' roots suffocating in the water which means near constant direct sunlight. Additionally, the water in the environment is usually nutrient poor. So, basically this plant has two of the three ingredients it needs to survive, the third being nutrients to grow.

Due to the lack of nutrients the plants adapted to catch insects. Additionally, these plants have gotten really good at absorbing any nutrients that land on them, so you are not actually allowed to touch them or risk chemical burns wherever you touch the plant. When I report them I usually make sure to keep my hands wet to dilute anything that might be on my hands. It also helps to mist them with water.

With regards to climate, these plants live in the warmer parts of the North Americas but still experience a winter dormancy period. During the colder seasons, the leaves (the pitchers) will start to brown and die. Once the frost hits all the leaves will die and all that will be left are the roots. The roots, or rather the rhizome, survives the winter and starts growing more leaves, and sometimes flowers, in the springtime.

blurbs.title: Shared traits: TL;DR
blurbs.text:
According to carnivorousplants.co:

Dos

  • Full direct sun
  • Unheated greenhouses

Don’ts

  • Terrariums are generally unsuitable
  • Don’t always cope well with strong winds

Dormancy

  • Cold winter dormancy between November and February
  • Leaves die when days get shorter
  • Winter is a good time to replant

Water

  • Distilled or rain water
    1. Avoid tap water, bottled water and filtered water
    2. Avoid fertiliser for similar reasons

blurbs.title: Shared traits: Environment
blurbs.text:
There are four main things that we need to match in terms of the environment: soil, water, light, and dormancy. The rest, bugs, will sort themselves out when the plants are outside, as mentioned they are great hunters.

For the soil I used one part peat moss and one part perlite. Peat moss by itself has very little to no nutrients the plant can use while having amazing water retention due to the shredded sphagnum moss inside. Warning, sphagnum moss is horrible at absorbing water when it is already dry as opposed to humid or damp! However, by itself peat moss will compact and become hard so it needs something to give it structure. For that I have used perlite which makes the soil fluffy and does not retain water well, or in other words provides drainage. The down side of this is that it is not easy to work with and apparently toxic to breathe. There are a couple of alternatives I have been wanting to try like coconut husks.

In this case water will be classified as humidity in the air or in the soil. It is important to understand that moisture in the soil is different from mud. In wet highlands, the ground would be fibrous and fluffy meaning that roots have access to water but also to air. There are two things we do to simulate humidity. The first is to put sphagnum moss on top of the soil to cover it. The moss itself holds moisture but as it covers the ground it helps the ground retain moisture as well. The second is that I like to have them stand in a deeper dish and a little bit of water. The bottom of the dish will have some aquarium gravel in it and the pot is less than 10% in the water, really not deep! This allows the soil to constantly absorb moisture without the roots standing in water. The roots should never be submerged in water but should always have humidity around them.

images.name: sarracenia_roots
images.alt: The exposed root system of a sarracenia rhizome and crown.

blurbs.text:
For the bottom dish of water, I have tried using distilled water, rain water, and well water. With distilled and rain water I have noticed that the water will turn a black or brown colour and by the end of the year there were red little worms living in it. Not pleasant. With well water I usually have a lot of algae growing in, which does not harm the Sarracenia while also absorbing nutrients in the water. Algae and Sarracenias seem to have a symbiotic relationship in this case. The water will not be harmful to you or the plant, the water will not be smelly, and it is easy to clean with simple rinse and dollar-store strainer. I will note that I live in North America meaning that untreated well water is more or less exactly the water these plants are used to, so it makes sense to me that they grow well in it.

Light is an easy one if you can put the plants outside in the summer. They need a fair amount of sunlight, I have had them in places where they would get a good 12 hours of direct sunlight in 30 C weather and did not show a sign of stress. Slightly shaded light outside will also often do the trick. Remember, these plants live in the North Americas so the climate here is more or less perfect for them. The reason why I cannot grow them outdoors is that the winters where I am get much too cold. As they are dormant during the winter and the summers are perfect where I live, I do not keep them indoors much. I would imagine you would need strong lights.

Dormancy for these plants would happen around november, giving them until about march for dormancy. In this case dormancy means wait until the soil is just slightly moist, trim the leaves off, sprinkle sulphur on top of the soil/moss to avoid mold, and put them in a fridge. Since the plant is dormant, it will not grow or photosynthesize so it does not need its leaves but it also cannot be completely dry. The dormancy period lasts 3 to 4 months and after that the plants can be taken out again. Having the plants at about 3C in the fridge seems to be cold enough that it simulates winter for these plants, freezing them should be avoided and will likely kill them.

images.name: sarracenia_young
images.alt: A picture of a young Sarracenia Farnhamii.

blurbs.title: Shared traits: Water and Fertilizer
blurbs.text:
These plants primarily get their nutrients from digesting insects as their environments generally do not offer nutrients otherwise. Distilled or rain water is often recommended, however I have had success with well water. Well water is clean and has some minerals but does not seem to harm the plants even when directly watered. With that said, water that has chlorine or water that has been softened are generally not good for plants and will be deadly to these plants due to how well they have adapted to absorbing nutrients.

With regards to fertiliser, these plants generally do not need any. If they are indoors and are not particularly catching much, you can take a tiny bit of all purpose fertiliser, mix it into water and spray the plants with it. If the plants are catching bugs then this is generally not needed.

blurbs.title: Shared traits: Catching insects
blurbs.text:
They produce a nectar around the brim of the opening. This nectar is sweet, it is compared to the nectar found in flowers. The brim will have visible beads of nectar. I touched a bead once and it was really sticky and smelled sweet. I want to know what it tastes like but I also don't wanna share a meal with flies if I can help it. This nectar is meant to attract insects to the opening of the pitcher. I have noticed that flies will crawl all over the plant and I suspect that the whole plant is sweet to lure insects. Once they insect notices the nectar they generally attempt to eat it without falling into the hole. The underside of the part of the leaf that covers the opening, has many little hairs that the insects cannot hold onto. This design makes the nectar uncomfortable for the flies to reach from the open end, whereas the underside of the leaf is not a place they can stand. Once they try, the tumble into the plant pitcher. Once the bug falls inside the pitcher, they have great difficulty getting out which is for different reasons depending on which subspecies. However, the nectar around the brim and the little hairs are generally how these plants catch their prey. Additionally, flies are attracted to the smell of other dead flies so the plants only attracts more insects both with more leaves that provide a sweet aroma as well as the stench of decaying insects. Generally, I don't notice a smell because the plants are really good at absorbing the nutrients.

I read it somewhere, but I have also witnessed that spiders like to make webs on these plants as it attracts a lot of insects, often inevitably leading to the spider falling into the plant.

images.name: sarracenia_purpurea
images.alt: Sarracenia purpurea where the hairs on the underside of the leaf are visible.

blurbs.title: Different traits: Trapping and digesting
blurbs.text:
This is where the two really distinguish themselves, as they use similar methods of catching their prey, using nectar and hairs, they trap and digest the insects in different ways.

The Sarracenia Farnhamii, has a part of the leaf that covers the opening to prevent any rain water from collecting in it. When the pitcher opens up, it is initially empty and the inside is also lined with a similar hair that it uses to catch the bug. When the unsuspecting insect falls in it will try to crawl or fly out leading to it rubbing against the hairs lining the inside of the pitcher. Rubbing the leaves causes the plant to produce what is effectively a weak acid to digest the insect. The more the insect struggles the more acid the plant releases. The acid is produced when the hairs are stimulated and stops shortly after. Once the plant catches more bugs, they will fall on top of the bugs that are already being digested, causing more digestive fluid to run down the pitcher and on top of the bugs below. The pitcher is also long and narrow, designed to squeeze the insects inside to cause more digestive fluid production.

The Sarracenia Purpurea, on the other hand, does not cover the top part of the pitcher deliberately to catch rain water. The pitchers themselves are also much shorter and wider, to support the weight of the water and to have more capacity to store it. When the insect falls into the pitcher, it will be trapped in the water. The walls of the pitchers are also made so the insects have trouble climbing them and to absorb nutrients. Once the insect dies and decays, the plant will absorb the nutrients from the water. When more insects fall in, they struggle and stir up the water with all the bits of decaying insects causing the mixture to swirl around which helps the plant absorb it even more.

images.alt: A picture of fully grown Sarracenia Farnhamii.

plants.name: Nepenthes Ventrata
plants.introduction: This is another carnivorous plant, and though it is also sometimes referred to as a pitcher plant it is a different species than Sarracenias. These plants are native to Asia and can grow in a variety of areas. These plants use a similar yet also unique way to catch their prey. This is a species I always wanted to have! plants.name: Grow lights
plants.introduction: I have wanted to learn more about grow lights and the more I learn the more it feels simple, yet incredibly complex at the same time. As I am mostly relying on a rudimentary understanding of physics, there are a few components that need to be well understood and that took me some time to figure out. Since I am not even sure what makes a grow light different from a regular light, I first need to find that out. This means that I will also need to know more about light sources such as LEDs and, electromagnetic waves.

blurbs.title: What is light?
blurbs.text: Plants need sunlight to grow. Sunlight offers light within all the colours of the spectrum. This light is what plants use as well as heat to photosynthesize and grow. The image shows what range of electromagnetic waves the sun produces, where 380 to about 780 nanometers is visible to humans. We can see that there is a bit more blue light being produced but across the board the lights are all produced at similar quantities. Source wtamu.edu/~cbaird.

blurbs.title: What light do plants need?
blurbs.text: Plants need light for photosynthesis, photo- meaning light. There are in depth explanations of the chemical properties that allow plants to do this, provided by bio.libretexts.org. In short, there are two types of chlorophyll, but they have similar light spectrum requirements. Both types of chlorophyll need a lot of blue light in the 350 to 450 nm range, as well as some red light in the 650 to 700 nm range. This is why you will see some grow lights that are purple, as they will have just blue and red light. Note, these are what the plants need for successful chlorophyll production but this is not the only process that goes on in the plant. According to cre.science each range in the spectrum plays a role in a plants life.

blurbs.title: What is an LED?
blurbs.text:
In general the way an LED works is well described in a video by Veritasium - Why It Was Almost Impossible to Make the Blue LED, a key takeaway in this context is understanding that LEDs can produce specific light colours (wavelengths). Since LEDs are so much more efficient and do not produce nearly as much heat as incandescent light bulbs, they are preferred. For reference, a standard incandescent light will use 60 Watts per hour, whereas the same lamp but LED will use 5 Watts per hour. That means that the cost of powering the incandescent light for one hour can power the same LED light for 12 hours! Plants do need heat, but this allows for there to be other sources of heat and it makes it easier to control the temperature in general. I have used regular incandescent lights as heat lamps before, in certain cases it really works well.

White light LEDs have different amounts of colours in the spectrum as seen in the image provided by softlights.org. Since they are likely a blue LED with a coating, the way the light colours can be controlled through what is known as Kelvin or warmth of light. The lower ends like 2700K white light has little blue light whereas the higher 5000K has a lot of blue light. Sunlight, however, has all the colours in the spectrum also referred to as full spectrum light. This means that to achieve this with LEDs we need enough of each one to simulate full spectrum light.

images.name: led_spectral_graphs
images.alt: Light spectrum production of various white lights.

blurbs.title: RGB LED light?
blurbs.text: The reason why RGB lights are said not to work by ncbi.nlm.nih.gov is due to the specific colour wavelengths emitted. These wavelengths mimic the full colour spectrum and are not chosen for plants but rather for humans and are thus argued to be suboptimal. RGB lights are also generally more expensive than white light LEDs.

images.name: rbg_led_spectrum
images.alt: Light spectrum production of RGB LED lights.

blurbs.title: Infrared light
blurbs.text: On the larger wavelengths we have infrared light. Infrared is also sometimes referred to as heat since that is how we experience it. This can be done through light bulbs or through heat elements. Plants do not use infrared directly, but rather rely on the heat to keep them alive. However, temperature plays a role in a plant's growth as well as some temperatures promote growth, while others do not. There is an extensive article about this by Kinuka Ohtaka et al. in a study about how day and night temperatures promote tomato seedling growth.. In short, the changes in temperature will affect growth as plants have optimal ranges of growth. When plants experience high temperatures they will be stressed, while low temperatures make them go dormant. Note, plants will stop growing after a certain point but it is not going to be harmful and may even be beneficial for the plant to "rest". Any plants I have in the house grow real slow, as soon as I put them outside they shoot up and I admit that light is likely a factor but temperature would be as well.

images.name: full_spectrum_with_UV
images.alt: The full light spectrum including UV and infrared.

blurbs.title: Ultraviolet light
blurbs.text:
On the other side of the spectrum, we have UV light. This light has high energy and is even warned to be dangerous for humans, especially your eyes and skin. Most if the higher energy UV rays, including UV-C and UV-B, are filtered out by the atmosphere leaving mostly UV-A with a little UV-B rays. According to Laura Llorens et al. in Editorial: Ultraviolet Radiation: Friend or Foe for Plants?, UV-A and UV-B light is important for certain developments in plants. UV light can be harmful in large doses but plants have adapted to these rays, and they should not be cosnidered as a regulatory stiumulus rather than a stressor. Even UV within the range of 385 nm increased plant growth. Hydrobuilder.com argues that they increase resitance to disease due to the ability to create a larger variety of proteins. I am not a chemist, but this makes sense to me as there is always the activation energy to a chemical reaction, or in other words the amount of energy required to start a reaction.

The UV index will also change throughout the year just as the infrared (heat) does. There is chart for NYC UV index, but it provides a good reference to understanding that UV index changes intensity throughout the year and what the average UV index in a day looks like. Right now, I am interested in the shape of the slope as well.

images.name: uv_index
images.alt: The UV index for each month of the year.

blurbs.title: What is a grow light?
blurbs.text: A Grow light is a light made to mimic the full colour spectrum, especially the colours needed to make chlorophyll. There are many different methods and strategies that different companies seem to employ to achieve to make full colour spectrum lights.

blurbs.title: What is fertiliser?
blurbs.text: Plants need fertiliser to grow.” We’ve all heard this statement at one point or another but what does that mean? Well, I am here to explain that. Instead of it meaning, “Go to the nearest plant store or supermarket and buy some general purpose fertiliser.” What it actually means is that the plant needs minerals. Much like your body needs certain minerals for growth and maintenance, plants do as well. So really, when talking about fertiliser we are talking about minerals that the plants need to grow.

blurbs.title: What are minerals?
blurbs.text:
Luckily, “Minerals are substances that are naturally formed on Earth” - byjus. These minerals are then used by the plants to grow. For example, onions need sulphur in the soil and in return they store sulphur in them. Another example is cucumbers, which need potassium in the soil to grow and guess what’s inside cucumbers, potassium, among many other minerals. Coincidentally, from plants is where we get a lot of our minerals, since we cannot digest dirt.

The problem is that when we are farming plants in a small-ish area and they use up the same minerals, at some point certain minerals will deplete and there are two major ways that we can combat this. The first and easiest, plant other plants in that area. Different plants need different minerals so while one plant may struggle in a particular spot, another plant may thrive. And the second, of course, being that we retrieve those minerals from somewhere and put them in the ground ourselves. However, those minerals are often in some form that plants can absorb and then we call it fertiliser.

blurbs.title: How do minerals not deplete in nature?
blurbs.text: We have forests that have been standing for hundreds of years, they are still healthy lush plants. Yet, we plant tomatoes in the same bed for a few years and each year the plants do worse and eventually they won’t grow at all… How can that be? Never underestimate the power of an ecosystem.

blurbs.title: Where do we find minerals?
blurbs.text: As mentioned, often just putting the pure mineral in the ground will not help the plant. For example, plants need calcium. A huge source is eggshells, so we can crush up the eggshells to a powder and add it to the soil of our plants. At this point, we will have to wait for the calcium to break down first at which point the plant can use it. The breaking down of these minerals can happen in a variety of ways including bacteria, insects, worms, and I’m sure there are more but I don’t know them all.

blurbs.title: What minerals do plants need?
blurbs.text: There are people far more knowledgeable than me who have worked on this and published what they found! :)

blurbs.title: What is electroculture?
blurbs.text: I have heard of this term but I know nothing about it, one of these days I will figure out what it is.

iterations.introduction: I really like the idea of self-sustainability, which is also probably why I like renewable energy! The concept of putting plants in a closed jar still amazes me and I have wanted to try making some in the past with little success. Of all the ones I have made only two have survived so far as they usually end up being taken over by mold. I wanted to document here the guides and resources I have found and for the next ones I make, I want to document the process so that hopefully I can replicate it in the future.

blurbs.title: Fall 2021, Personal Project
blurbs.text: Rapid Exploring Random Trees is a method of exploring a terrain. The idea is that you place a target in a random location on the screen, which is not drawn, then find the closest point of the path already travelled and take a step into the direction of the random point. Continue this until you reach the goal. I learned about this a while back in a course and have now re-implemented it mostly for amusement, I just love watching it explore. It's interesting that even though it takes a random step, it still finds the goal even in really tough spots. See the code on Github.

blurbs.title: Fall 2021, Personal Project
blurbs.text: ACO is a meta-heuristic for combinatorial optimization problems, which is a fancy way of saying routing problems. The most basic instance of a routing problem is the famous "Travelling-salesman problem" introduced by Merrill M. Flood in 1955. The basic idea is for a single salesman to visit every city with the shortest possible distance. The reason this is a combinatorial problem is because for n cities there are n! different solutions. For example, if there are 10 cities then there are 3628800 different combinations of possible routes, where one route will be the shortest. Since finding the optimal solution when n is large is not possible within a reasonable amount of time, better methods need to be developed. In ACO, the variation is that there are many ants and they make choices based on probability which is based on the distance. Meaning, a given ant can see all the cities and each city will have a probability of being visited based on the distance. So, the closest will have the highest probability and the furthest the least. Additionally, when an ant travels down a path it lays pheromones which can be seen by other ants. In which case the probability will be based on both the distance and the pheromone strength. I implemented this as a visual representation to see how the algorithm works based on a tutorial by Budi Santosa (2015). See the code on Github.

images.alt: A short animation demonstrating how Ant Colony Optimization searches through nodes.

blurbs.title: Winter 2021, Personal Project
blurbs.text:
Least square regression simply tries to minimise the distance to all points. Ridge regression takes the error into account and tries to minimise error by giving points a weight that indicates how much this point should contribute to the model. For example, an outlier is not desirable so giving it a small weight means that it will be less likely to make the model incorrect. Additionally, once you can also use more advanced methods like nonlinear solutions. For now, I implemented the simplest version of the algorithm.

See the code on Github.

blurbs.title: Fall 2018, University Project
blurbs.text:
This is a particle system that I did for an assignment and then later slightly modified. It's a rather simple program, but it was fun to make. I also like the idea of using small particles to simulate things like smoke and fire.

The particles have mass and slightly change colour on every collision, which is only noticeable when the program runs for a few seconds.

blurbs.title: Summer 2016, Personal Project
blurbs.text:
Another personal project that simulates growing grass using particles. This whole program is procedurally generated. Each 'root' is made up of several blades of grass and each blade of grass is made up of several particles. The grass can grow and be mowed. I also worked on making it sway in the wind which was a challenge.

I have since learned more about optimising code and different strategies that I could have used to accomplish similar things, but I enjoyed writing it. When I wrote this program I didn't know that this is technically a particle system, I just had the idea and wanted to try it.
